references:
In federated learning deployments, data partitions across clients invariably exhibit non-iid behavior [19]. Thus, we begin by investigating the effect of adversarial training with non-iid data.
Details for the data partition strategy for non-iid data can be found in Section.Â 5.1.1
TableÂ 1 reports the performance of FedAvgAT for both natural training and adversarial training for all the three models. The number of local training epochs, E=1ğ¸1E=1. We also report results for centralized training (entire dataset available at the training site) for better comparison.

FedCurv, as described in Section.Â 2.2, has been shown to result in better performance as compared to FedAvg in the context of non-iid data distributionÂ [22]. We evaluate performance of FedCurvAT on non-iid data and its dependency on Eğ¸E.
TableÂ 2 compares the performance of FedCurvAT and FedAvgAT for different values of Eğ¸E for NIN, VGG and EMNIST-M models.

100 (70.0%, 38%) (71%, 37.5%) (67.2%, 35.3%) (70.4%, 38%)

references: We set out to solve the adversarial training problem with non-iid data split in a communication constrained setting. We vary the communication buget i.e maximum number of communication rounds and demonstrate how FedDynAT performs as compared to FedAvgAT and FedCurvAT. We evaluate FedAvgAT and FedCurvAT with multiple values of Eğ¸E and report performance corresponding to the best natural accuracy of the global model. TableÂ 4 shows the results for Network-in-network model for CIFAR10 dataset and TableÂ 5 shows that of EMNIST-M model for EMNIST dataset. We defer results with VGG to the Supplement.

FedAvg fusion with dynamic Eğ¸E: 
FedDynAT uses the FedCurvature fusion algorithm. We consider another baseline where we replace the fusion algorithm with FedAvg and refer to it as FedAvgDynAT.
The results with NIN in TableÂ 4 demonstrate that FedDynAT outperforms this baseline. In SectionÂ 4.2 we established that FedCurvAT results in improvement over FedAvgAT for higher Eğ¸E. A high E0subscriptğ¸0E_{0} for our E-schedule contributes to better eventual performance with FedDynAT over FedAvgDynAT.
We find FedAvgDynAT performs similar to FedDynAT for EMNIST dataset for the particular communication budget.
